item.title: Shoppers rush to the High Street as England stores reopen
item.description: Footfall jumped nearly 40% on Monday as pent-up demand led to queues outside Zara, Primark and others.

item.title: North Sea US jet crash: Pilot's body found
item.description: The F-15C Eagle, from the 48th Fighter Wing at RAF Lakenheath crashed shortly after 09:30 BST.

item.title: Black Lives Matter: We need action on racism not more reports, says David Lammy
item.description: The Labour MP's comments come after the PM announced a new commission looking at racial inequality.

item.title: Harlesden shooting: Bullet 'missed toddler's artery by millimetre'
item.description: Five men have been arrested in connection with the shooting but no one has been charged.

item.title: Coronavirus: Evening update as shops reopen, and England star makes free school meals plea
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus outbreak this evening.

item.title: Man jailed for urinating at PC Keith Palmer memorial during protest
item.description: Andrew Banks had drunk 16 pints and was in central London to "protect statues", a court hears.

item.title: Brexit: New momentum needed in trade talks, says UK and EU
item.description: The PM says the talks need "a bit of oomph" and sees no reason why a deal cannot be "done in July".

item.title: Secondary pupils back in England - but most only part-time
item.description: Secondary pupils in England back in school, but survey suggests most no more than a day a week.

item.title: Coronavirus: Sturgeon wants 'normal' schooling back 'as quickly as possible'
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon says she wants pupils to be back in classrooms full-time "as quickly as is safe and feasible".

item.title: Luce Douady: French 16-year-old climber dies from fall
item.description: Luce Douady was seen as a future star of the climbing world after wowing in senior competition.

item.title: Coronavirus: NI's hotels and bars can reopen from 3 July
item.description: Economy Minister Diane Dodds confirms NI's hospitality sector can reopen earlier than planned.

item.title: Joe Wicks to scale back online PE classes to three days a week
item.description: The Body Coach is moving to a reduced timetable, saying he needs "a little bit of a break".

item.title: Coronavirus: The first thing I bought when the shops reopened
item.description: As stores across England selling non-essential goods opened their doors, we asked people in Milton Keynes what they bought.

item.title: Queues and social distancing as shops reopen in England
item.description: Non-essential retailers open their doors with strict safety measures.

item.title: Families fear being 'left with zero' if school meal scheme ends
item.description: Families say they rely on food vouchers and back Marcus Rashford's plea to keep them over the summer.

item.title: 'I was in prison, now I'm training Jadon Sancho'
item.description: Mike Boateng wants his jail experience to help other young footballers avoid trouble.

item.title: London protests: 'We stopped somebody from being killed'
item.description: Patrick Hutchinson was pictured carrying a man to safety following a clash between demonstrators.

item.title: One family, two generations of protest
item.description: People in Los Angeles took to the streets to call for justice in 1992. Has anything changed since then?

item.title: Incredible 'lightning rainbows' illuminate UK skies
item.description: The rare combination was captured by BBC Weather Watchers during storms at the weekend.

item.title: Sixth-form students use art to express life in lockdown
item.description: Sixth-formers show their creative expression in an online exhibition during the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: X Factor's Misha B claims show pushed 'angry black girl narrative' on her
item.description: The singer says the show "created this narrative of me being over confident because I'm black".

item.title: Kenya: Police brutality in the battle against coronavirus in Mathare
item.description: In one of Kenya's poorest settlements, brutal policing of a curfew is causing more problems than Covid-19.

item.title: Birdwatcher, 14, making the most of lockdown wildlife
item.description: Indy Kiemel Green, 14, says youngsters do not see wildlife as something 'cool'.

item.title: Fruit picking: New intakes of fruit and veg picking Brits
item.description: Meet the Brits becoming fruit and veg pickers to help with harvest during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'It's very exciting to be returning to work'
item.description: Non-essential shops in England can reopen on Monday and many staff can't wait to get back to business.

item.title: Cherry Wilson: Should I remove or reply to my racist Facebook friend?
item.description: When someone you know starts posting racist stuff, what's the best way of dealing with it?

item.title: Black Lives Matter: Have racial inequality reviews led to action?
item.description: A number of reviews have looked at race and equality over the years, but has the government taken action?

item.title: Coronavirus: Isle of Man becomes first in British Isles to live without lockdown
item.description: Many aspects of life on the island resume as it scraps social distancing rules.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your lockdown stories revisited
item.description: We revisit the people who spoke to us during lockdown to ask: how did you change?

item.title: 'It's not talked about': Female artists speak out about racism
item.description: Michelle Gayle, Fleur East, Sabrina from Mis-Teeq and Aluna Francis have all shared their experiences.

item.title: Coronavirus: Contact-tracing apps face further hitches
item.description: Norway has to halt use of its app and researchers report a major flaw in Australia's tool.

item.title: Rwanda genocide: 'I am a mother - I killed some children's parents'
item.description: Female perpetrators of the Rwandan genocide speak about their crimes and desire for reconciliation.

item.title: Coronavirus: The learners waiting to take their driving tests
item.description: Pupils and instructors alike are facing a nervous wait to find out when they can get back behind the wheel.

item.title: 'I was heartbroken, I never thought I would find someone like her'
item.description: How lost love inspired Justin McLeod to set up popular dating app Hinge.

item.title: How Jessie Ware's podcast made her music 'faster, sexier, naughtier'
item.description: The pop star says she was "scared and nervous". Then she made a hit podcast with her mum.

item.title: Coronavirus: Fact-checking claims it might have started in August 2019
item.description: Does a study suggesting possibility of coronavirus cases in Wuhan much earlier than reported stand up to scrutiny?

item.title: Arteta 'pretty positive' on new Aubameyang deal
item.description: Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta says he is "pretty positive" about agreeing a new deal with striker Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang.

item.title: Hearts start relegation legal challenge after expanded top flight rejected
item.description: Hearts will mount a legal challenge against their relegation after clubs fail to back league reconstruction.

item.title: Whyte takes legal action against WBC after Fury-Joshua 'agreed'
item.description: Dillian Whyte takes legal action against the WBC after Tyson Fury-Anthony Joshua agree two-fight deal, Chris Eubank Jr takes a dig at Billy Joe Saunders, plus more in this week's Fight Talk.

item.title: 'The eyes of the world will be on us' - Villa boss ready for Premier League restart
item.description: Aston Villa boss Dean Smith says "the eyes of the world will be on us" when his side host Sheffield United in the first Premier League game since the coronavirus shutdown.

item.title: What shops are open?
item.description: Non-essential shops have reopened in England, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Coronavirus: What will clothes shopping look like?
item.description: From Monday all non-essential shops are allowed to reopen in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's happening to free school meals this summer?
item.description: Some parts of the UK will scrap free school meal support in the summer.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are becoming compulsory for people using public transport in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing in England aimed at helping single people cut off from family and friends.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Nine million people have accessed the scheme, which will move to its next phase in July.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are going back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Can I stay with my boyfriend now? And other questions
item.description: Questions about support bubbles, and other coronavirus topics

item.title: Coronavirus: Five ways shopping will be different from now on
item.description: Shops in England are preparing to welcome customers back but what will the "new normal" look like?

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: The first "support bubbles" of people who can meet indoors has been announced in England and Northern Ireland.

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is a recession?
item.description: The world faces the worst recession for 80 years. But what does that mean?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work in England?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, bars, cafes and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Pubs and restaurants in England are expected to reopen in July, but can I meet a friend for a meal?

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: Five unanswered questions on the travel quarantine rules
item.description: Travellers to the UK now have to self-isolate for 14 days. But how will the rules work in practice?

item.title: When can I ride an e-scooter legally?
item.description: With people told to avoid public transport, the government's hoping to trial e-scooter rental schemes.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Can thermal cameras help spot coronavirus?
item.description: The devices allow a person's temperature to be checked from a distance, but are not always reliable.

item.title: Coronavirus and face coverings: the correct way to wear them
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the chance of going on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Coronavirus: Saffron Walden dentist shows new appointment routine
item.description: Join us on a walk through a dental surgery to show what you might face at your next appointment.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are protests legal amid lockdown?
item.description: Black Lives Matter protests continue in the UK - but are they illegal under restrictions on gatherings?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why are international comparisons difficult?
item.description: Should you be comparing Covid-19 statistics between countries?

item.title: Can superspreading be stopped?
item.description: Identifying superspreading events could be crucial in the fight against the virus, scientists say.

item.title: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: NHS test & trace: Does contact tracing stop coronavirus?
item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: George Floyd death: 'The same happened to my son'
item.description: An immigrant community divided by the anti-racist protests rocking the US.
